translation.title: Completed Building
translation.short_def: A legally approved and fully completed property.
translation.long_def: A completed building is a property with a valid building permit, constructed accordingly, and officially considered finished. In Croatia, legal construction status is required for property registration, financing, leasing, and resale.

translation.title: Depreciation
translation.short_def: Tax distribution of property costs over several years.
translation.long_def: Depreciation allows investors to distribute the acquisition or construction costs of a property for tax purposes over a defined period. In Croatia, different depreciation options apply depending on the type of use, especially in leasing or commercial use.

translation.title: Sole Ownership
translation.short_def: Full property ownership by a single party.
translation.long_def: Sole ownership means 100 percent of a property is owned by an individual or an entity. There are no shared ownership stakes with third parties. This form of ownership simplifies decision processes, sales, and property charges.

translation.title: Down Payment (Kapara)
translation.short_def: Contractual security in real estate purchases.
translation.long_def: Kapara is a customary down payment in Croatia made during the signing of a preliminary or purchase agreement. It secures both parties in the contract. Depending on the contract terms, it may be forfeited upon withdrawal or returned double.

translation.title: Building Permit
translation.short_def: Official approval for the construction of a structure.
translation.long_def: The building permit confirms that a construction project complies with applicable building and zoning regulations. In Croatia, properties without a valid building permit are considered legally risky and may hinder usage, sale, or financing.

translation.title: Buildability
translation.short_def: Legal possibility of constructing on a plot.
translation.long_def: Buildability describes whether and to what extent a property can be developed. It results from land use designation, zoning plans, and local building regulations and is a central value factor for properties.

translation.title: Encumbrance (Land Register)
translation.short_def: Registered restriction or obligation in the land register.
translation.long_def: Encumbrances such as mortgages, easements, or residency rights are recorded in the Croatian land register. They can significantly affect the use, value, and availability of a property and must be reviewed before any purchase.

translation.title: Closing
translation.short_def: Legal completion of a real estate purchase.
translation.long_def: Closing refers to the final step of a real estate transaction, including payment, contract signing, and title transfer. In Croatia, this process is typically notarized.

translation.title: Due Diligence
translation.short_def: Comprehensive legal and economic real estate review.
translation.long_def: Due Diligence involves examining ownership, building legality, encumbrances, taxes, and usage possibilities. It is essential in Croatia to minimize legal and financial risks before purchase.

translation.title: Easement (Servitude)
translation.short_def: Registered land use right favoring third parties.
translation.long_def: An easement is a registered right in the land registry allowing or prescribing specific uses by another person or property, such as rights of way or utility easements. It can affect market value.

translation.title: Double Taxation Agreement
translation.short_def: Agreement to prevent double taxation of income.
translation.long_def: Double Taxation Agreements determine which state has the taxation rights for income from real estate. For international investors in Croatia, they are essential to avoid double taxation.

translation.title: Ownership
translation.short_def: Legally protected control over a property.
translation.long_def: Ownership refers to the comprehensive right to manage, use, encumber, or dispose of a property. In Croatia, ownership of real estate only arises with the registration in the land register.

translation.title: Transfer of Ownership
translation.short_def: Legal transfer of property ownership to the buyer.
translation.long_def: The transfer of ownership in Croatia is done by registering the new owner in the land register. Prerequisites are a valid purchase contract and proof of payment.

translation.title: Development
translation.short_def: Connection of a property to infrastructure.
translation.long_def: Development involves connecting a property to public infrastructure like roads, electricity, water, and sewage. The degree of development significantly affects buildability and market value.

translation.title: Financing
translation.short_def: Equity or debt financing of a property.
translation.long_def: Financing describes the provision of equity and debt to acquire or build a property. In Croatia, financing is available for foreigners, but certain conditions apply.

translation.title: Land Use Designation
translation.short_def: Determination of allowable land use.
translation.long_def: Land use designation defines how a property can be used, such as building land, green space, or tourist zone. It is part of spatial planning and is the basis for all construction decisions.

translation.title: Land Register
translation.short_def: Public register for ownership and encumbrances.
translation.long_def: The Croatian Land Register is a public register where ownership, encumbrances, and rights on real estate are recorded. Only registered rights are legally binding.

translation.title: Plot
translation.short_def: Unbuilt or buildable land.
translation.long_def: A plot is a defined piece of land that can be built upon or remain undeveloped. Usage and development depend on zoning, infrastructure, and construction regulations.

translation.title: Mortgage
translation.short_def: A lien registered in the land register.
translation.long_def: A mortgage is a lien recorded in the land register in favor of a lender. It serves to secure loans and represents a significant encumbrance on the property.

translation.title: Real Estate Valuation
translation.short_def: Determining the market value of a property.
translation.long_def: Real estate valuation involves determining the current market value of a property. In Croatia, valuations consider location, condition, usage possibilities, legal situation, and market environment. It is relevant for purchase decisions, financing, and investment analyses.

translation.title: Property Purchase
translation.short_def: Acquisition of ownership in a property.
translation.long_def: Property purchase in Croatia involves contract signing, payment, and land registry entry. Foreign buyers should note legal, tax, and formal considerations.

translation.title: Investment
translation.short_def: Capital investment aiming for value increase or return.
translation.long_def: A real estate investment targets ongoing income, value enhancement, or both. In Croatia, location, usage, tax conditions, and legal security are crucial factors.

translation.title: Purchase Agreement
translation.short_def: Legal agreement on property acquisition.
translation.long_def: The purchase agreement outlines the rights and obligations of buyer and seller. In Croatia, it must meet specific formal requirements and forms the basis for payment and ownership transfer.

translation.title: Legalization
translation.short_def: Retroactive legal recognition of a building.
translation.long_def: Legalization refers to the process of retroactively approving a structure built without a valid building permit. In Croatia, it is subject to strict conditions and is not always feasible.

translation.title: Luxury Property
translation.short_def: High-quality property with above-average features.
translation.long_def: Luxury properties are distinguished by exclusive location, high-quality construction, design, privacy, and special features. In Croatia, they are often found in coastal areas or on islands.

translation.title: Market Value
translation.short_def: Price achievable in the open market.
translation.long_def: Market value refers to the likely price achievable for a property sale under normal market conditions. It is determined by supply, demand, location, condition, and legal considerations.

translation.title: Co-ownership
translation.short_def: Joint ownership by multiple parties.
translation.long_def: In co-ownership, a property is owned by several individuals in specific shares. Decisions regarding its use, sale, or encumbrance require, depending on the arrangement, the consent of all co-owners.

translation.title: Notary
translation.short_def: Public official for contract notarization.
translation.long_def: The notary assists in Croatian property purchases by certifying signatures and notarizing contracts. They ensure the formal legal security of the purchase process.

translation.title: OIB Number
translation.short_def: Personal Croatian tax identification number.
translation.long_def: The OIB number is a unique tax identification number required in Croatia for most legal and tax-related processes, including property purchase and ownership registration.

translation.title: Yield
translation.short_def: Return on real estate investment relative to its outlay.
translation.long_def: Yield measures the financial return of a property relative to the capital invested. It takes into account rental income, costs, taxes, and potential value increases.

translation.title: Tax Obligation
translation.short_def: Obligation to pay taxes.
translation.long_def: Tax obligation describes the legal requirement to remit taxes. In Croatia, property acquisition, ownership, and income taxes may apply.

translation.title: Easement
translation.short_def: Registry-backed usage rights for third parties.
translation.long_def: An easement is a servitude entered in the land register granting certain persons or properties usage rights, such as rights of way or utility rights. Easements can affect the use and value of a property.

translation.title: Handover Protocol
translation.short_def: Documented transfer of a property to the buyer.
translation.long_def: The handover protocol records the condition of the property at the time of transfer. It includes details on defects, meter readings, keys, and fittings, and ensures legal security for both parties.

translation.title: Value Added Tax (VAT)
translation.short_def: Sales tax on certain real estate transactions.
translation.long_def: Value Added Tax (VAT) may apply when purchasing new properties or for commercial usage. In Croatia, the standard rate is 25 percent. Whether VAT or real estate transfer tax is applicable depends on the type and age of the property.

translation.title: Rental
translation.short_def: Temporary transfer of property in exchange for payment.
translation.long_def: Rental involves the temporary transfer of property in exchange for payment. In Croatia, fiscal, legal, and permit requirements must be observed, especially in short-term tourist rentals.

translation.title: Preliminary Agreement
translation.short_def: Provisional binding agreement prior to the purchase contract.
translation.long_def: A preliminary agreement outlines the essential aspects of a planned property purchase before finalizing the purchase contract. It usually includes the purchase price, payment terms, and a Kapara, which is a deposit in Croatia to secure the contract.

translation.title: Zoning Plan
translation.short_def: Plan for the permitted use of land plots.
translation.long_def: The zoning plan is an urban planning tool that specifies how land can be used. It forms the basis for building permits and investment decisions.

translation.title: Interest
translation.short_def: Cost for borrowed capital.
translation.long_def: Interest is the compensation for the use of borrowed capital. In real estate financing, interest rates significantly affect the total costs and profitability of an investment.
